Situation1: Laundry needs to be done so clean clothes are available for the family’s activities.
Expectation2: Officiate at life cycle events such as weddings, bar/bat mitzvahs, and funerals.
Situation2: A couple has made an initial inquiry about his availability for a wedding over a year away.
Story: I was folding the last of the towels when my phone buzzed. My husband’s voice echoed from the hallway, “Did you remember to wash the kids’ uniforms for tomorrow?” I glanced at the overflowing laundry basket, guilt prickling at my conscience. I’d promised to keep up with the chores this week, especially with the kids’ schedules so packed. As I reached for the detergent, my phone buzzed again—an email from a young couple in the congregation. They wanted to meet, to talk about their wedding, and they were hoping I could officiate. The date was more than a year away, but they wanted to meet tonight, since they were only in town for the weekend. I could hear the kids arguing upstairs, the laundry still waiting, and my husband’s footsteps coming closer. My mind raced, torn between the needs of my family and the expectations of my community. I stood in the laundry room, phone in hand, heart pounding, caught between two worlds that both needed me, right now.
